citation.article-title: Thermococcus waiotapuensis sp. nov., an extremely thermophilic archaeon isolated from a freshwater hot spring

p.s: Description of Thermococcus waiotapuensis sp. nov.
Thermococcus waiotapuensis (wa.io.ta.puen'sis M.L.adj. waiotapuensis, from the Waiotapu hot spring (New Zealand))
Coccoid-shaped and flagellated cells between 0.7 and 1.5 μm in diameter.
Temperature range for growth from 60 to 90 °C; optimum at 85 °C.
Range of growth from pH 5.0 to 8.0, with the optimum at around pH 7.0.
Optimum NaCl concentration was 5.4 g l–1 (5.4%), and growth was supported at NaCl concentrations lower than 14 g l–1.
Strictly heterotrophic, growing optimally on peptone, tryptone, yeast extract, and other complex proteinaceous substrates.
Growth is also supported by a defined mixture of amino acids.
Starch, maltose, and pyruvate can be utilized.
Growth occurs in the presence of elemental sulfur, although it can be substituted by cystine or thioglycollate.
Isolated from Waiotapu, a terrestrial, freshwater hot spring in New Zealand.
